TextBlock.Text: SENNETTI: While Nesia heads the study of the Dree’s physiology, I would like to take the opportunity to share aspects of their culture that I learned of during my translation of their language.

SENNETTI: Rather than engaging in scientific pursuits, the Dree seem to have certain… influences over the <color=purple>Bramble</color>. This includes influencing the growth of the vines (as demonstrated by those holding together <color=orange>Shattered Hearth</color>) and even some level of communication with the plant.
NESIA: Hypothesis: if they are able to communicate with the vines, they may be able to inform us what became of the launched escape pods.
OKALIS: Resuming our studies, the Dree seem to gain most of their nutrition from anglerfish eggs, domesticating and breeding the fish to do so.
AZOLLA: Interesting. I wonder how they began this practice? I can’t imagine that anglerfish eggs would have been terribly easy for their ancestors to procure.

SENNETTI: I believe I do actually have the answer to this question, as an old Dree story may explain it. The story is too long to transcribe here, but I had previously recorded it on <color=orange>Magma’s Recursion</color>.
NESIA: Agreed. Even now the Dree continue to keep lights on their homes to ward off any wandering fish.
NESIA: I have observed that the Dree seem rather… stagnant. They seem uninterested in exploring beyond their immediate vicinity and appear to have entirely accepted their current situation.

OKALIS: I would agree, Nesia. We have also observed how this can be destructive, as they were unwilling to take the necessary risks to retrieve Ditylum when he became stranded at the <color=orange>Venomous Reject</color>, unable to cross the <color=orange>Nursery</color>.
AZOLLA: Fortunately, that event seems to have changed their outlook considerably, as well as inspiring them to put more trust in us than they did previously.
